info.description: Enable users to login and register by using a social login identity provider.
info.title: Akamai: Identity Cloud Custom Provider API

get.description: Returns your social login applications. You use social login applications to create custom providers.

externalDocs.description: See documentation for this operation in Akamai's Identity Cloud Custom Provider API

schema.description: Returns your social login applications. You use a social login application to create custom providers.

_embedded.description: Navigable hypermedia links for your social login applications.

item.description: Navigable hypermedia links for your social login applications.

_links.description: Navigable hypermedia links for the social login application.

self.description: Navigable hypermedia link for a social login application.

href.description: Navigable hypermedia link for a social login application.

appid.description: Unique identifier of a social login application.

realm.description: Authentication domain for a social login application. Unless you use a custom domain, your social login applications are typically on the `rpxnow.com` domain. In that case, and if your domain is `my-domain.rpxnow.com`, your realm is `my-domain`.

_links.description: Navigable hypermedia links for a social login application.

item.description: Navigable hypermedia link for a social login application.

href.description: Navigable hypermedia for a social login application.

templated.description: Internal identifier for the social login application. For Identity Cloud use only.

self.description: Navigable hypermedia links for your social login applications.

href.description: Navigable hypermedia link for your social login applications.

total.description: Total number of social login applications available to you.

200.description: Information about your social login applications.

schema.description: Typically occurs if your path includes an invalid customer ID or application ID. Verify those values are correct, then try again.

parameters.description: Unique identifier of an Akamai customer. To verify your Akamai customer ID, log in to Console and, on the **Manage Application** page, check the value of the `customer_id` setting.

schema.description: Returns a social login application.

_links.description: Navigable hypermedia links for the custom providers.

custom-providers.description: Navigable hypermedia links for the custom providers.

href.description: Hypermedia link for the application's custom providers.

self.description: Navigable hypermedia links for the social login application.

href.description: Navigable hypermedia link to a social login application.

allowedTokenDomainPatterns.description: Domains that can communicate with the social login application. If `null`, any domain can communicate with your social login application.

appid.description: Unique identifier of a social login application.

createdAt.description: Timestamp indicating the creation date for the social login application.

customerid.description: Unique identifier your organization. Akamai issues you a customer ID when you subscribe to Identity Cloud.

enabledProviders.description: Social login providers ready for immediate use. If `null`, no providers are available for immediate use.

providers.description: Available social login providers, including those not yet ready for use. If `null`, the application doesn't have any social login providers'.

realm.description: Authentication domain for a social login application. Unless you use a custom domain, your social login applications are typically on the `rpxnow.com` domain. In that case, and if your domain is `my-domain.rpxnow.com`, your realm is `my-domain`.

secret.description: Password for the social login application.

updatedAt.description: Timestamp indicating the last update time for the social login application.

200.description: Information about a social login application.

schema.description: Typically occurs because your request path is incorrect or your request JSON is invalid.

Typically occurs because your token is invalid. Obtain a new access token and then try again. See [Get started](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud-custom-provider/reference/get-started) for more information on configuring custom provider authentication.

example.error: The requested resource was not found

schema.description: Typically occurs if your path includes an invalid customer ID or application ID. Verify those values are correct, then try again.

parameters.description: Unique identifier of an Akamai customer. To verify your Akamai customer ID, log in to Console and, on the **Manage Application** page, check the value of the `customer_id` setting.
parameters.name: customerId

parameters.description: Unique identifier of your Identity Cloud application. You can find your application ID on the Console's **Manage Application** page.
parameters.name: appId

parameters.description: Uses the `ETag` value to determine if an application or provider has changed since a specified time. To determine whether changes have been made, set the header in your request to the previous `ETag` value, then call your operation. See [Use Etags to check for custom provider updates](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/use-etags-to-check-for-custom-provider-updates) for more information.
parameters.name: If-None-Match

externalDocs.description: See documentation for this operation in Akamai's Identity Cloud Custom Provider API

schema.description: Creates a custom provider. Use custom providers for any social login identity providers Akamai didn't predefine.

attribute_map.description: **For use with OAuth, OpenID Connect, and SAML 2.0 providers.** Maps the user profile claims from a social login identity provider (IdP) to their corresponding Identity Cloud user profile attributes. For example, a `username` IdP claim might map to the Identity Cloud’s `displayName` attribute. Without this mapping you can’t copy information from users' social login accounts to their Identity Cloud accounts. When creating a map, list the Identity Cloud attribute first and the IdP attribute second. For example, the mapping `"/displayName": "/username"` maps Identity Cloud’s `displayName` attribute to the social login provider’s `username` claim. You need to prepend each attribute name with the slash (`/`) character. See [Map custom provider attributes](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/map-custom-provider-attributes) for more information. This documentation shows only one sample attribute. The attributes available to you depend on the identity provider and on how you configure Identity Cloud.

auth_url.description: **For use with OAuth, OpenID Connect, and SAML 2.0 providers.** URL of the identity provider’s authorization server. For OpenID Connect and OAuth 2.0, find this value in the provider’s documentation or, for OpenID Connect only, by looking for the `authorization_endpoint` entry in the website’s discovery document. For SAML 2.0 providers you can determine the URL by retrieving the provider’s SAML metadata and looking for the `SingleSignOnService` element and the `Location` attribute. Regardless of the protocol, the value needs to use the `https` scheme.

authn_context.description:
**For use with SAML 2.0 providers.** Enables or disables the `RequestedAuthnContext` element in SAML requests. If not `null`, this element instructs the SAML IdP to authenticate users by using a username and password. Typically this value makes no difference, because most SAML IdPs ignore the `RequestedAuthnContext` element. However, for some identity providers enabling this element prevents a user from authenticating. In those cases, use this member to disable the element. 
By default, Identity Cloud enables this member on all SAML providers prior to August 12, 2021 and disables it for providers after that date. If necessary, you can disable this member by setting the value to `null`.

class_ref.description: SAML authentication class. The only valid value is `PasswordProtectedTransport`, for use when a user authenticates with a password.

comparison.description: Specifies how the SAML provider determines the authentication flow. The supported `exact` value indicates the authentication context needs to match the `class_ref` exactly.

client_id.description: **For use with OpenID Connect providers.** Unique identifier of the authentication client users employ when logging in. The authentication client is the client you create on an identity provider’s developers site. Note that not all providers refer to this value as the _client ID_. Different providers might use such terms as _application ID_, _app ID_, or _API client ID_.  Use the `token_auth_method` member to specify how to use this `client_id`` with an OAuth provider.

client_secret.description: **For use with OpenID Connect providers.** Password for the authentication client. Not all providers call this a _client secret_. Some providers might refer to an _application secret_ or _app secret_, while others might use the term _API secret_ or _API key_. Use the `token_auth_method` member to specify how to use this member with an OAuth provider.

identifier_attribute.description: **For use with OAuth providers.** Attribute that uniquely identifies the user. For example, if the response from an OAuth provider includes a unique identifier `userid`, you might set this to `/userid`. Preface attribute names with `/`.

idp_certificate.description: **For use with SAML 2.0 providers.** X.509 certificate the identity provider uses to sign a SAML assertion. In a SAML assertion, the certificate is in the `<ds:X509Certificate>` section. In the `<ds:SignatureValue>` section you’ll find the public key, which authenticates the assertion.

idp_certificate_chain.description: **For use with SAML 2.0 providers.**  Certificates that complete the certificate chain. You only need this if you use a third-party Certificate Authority. If you use a self-signed SAML certificate, there’s no certificate chain to specify.

profile_url.description: **For use with OAuth and OpenID Connect  providers.** URL of the identity provider’s `userinfo` endpoint. You can find this setting in the provider’s documentation or, for OpenID Connect, by looking for the `userinfo_endpoint` entry in a website’s discovery document. The value needs to use the `https` scheme.

protocol.description: **For use with OAuth, OpenID Connect, and SAML 2.0 providers.** Authentication protocol of the identity provider. Valid values: `oauth2`, for OAuth 2.0, `openidconnect` for OpenID Connect, and `saml2` for Security Assertion Markup Language 2.0. After you create a custom provider, you can't change the protocol.

scopes.description: **For use with OAuth and OpenID Connect providers.** Specifies the user profile information the identity provider returns following authentication. Standard OpenID Connect scopes include `openid`, `email`, `phone`, `address`, and `profile`. However, many IdPs use custom scopes instead of, or in addition to, these standard scopes.

title.description: **For use with OAuth, OpenID Connect, and SAML 2.0 providers.** Name of a custom provider. Names need to be unique across a given social login application.

token_auth_method.description: **For use with OAuth providers.** Authentication method for calling the provider's token endpoint. Possible values are: `client_secret_post` or `client_secret_basic`. With `client_secret_post`, the client sends authentication information as part of the POST request body. With `client_secret_basic`, the client passes a user ID and password to the server as part of an `Authorization` header. For security reasons, only use the `client_secret_basic` method on a secure connection.

token_url.description: **For use with OAuth and OpenID Connect providers.** URL of the identity provider’s token endpoint. This setting is in the provider’s documentation or, for OpenID Connect only, by looking for the `token_endpoint` entry in the website’s discovery document. The value needs to use the `https` scheme.

ui.description: **For use with OAuth, OpenID Connect, and SAML 2.0 providers.** Specifies the custom provider name and icon that displays in the Hosted Login sign-in screen. This consists of two key-value pairs: `title` and `icon_url`.

icon_url.description: URL to the publicly accessible image as shown on the sign-in screen. Icons can use either `.png` or `.svg` files. This is optional, but if left off, it means no icon displays on the sign-in screen.

title.description: Name of the custom provider as it appears in the sign-in screen. Titles need to contain at least two, but no more than 200, characters. You need to include this value if you use this member.

schema.description: Provides information about the new provider. The last item in the response is the ID for the provider.
Navigable hypermedia link to configure the new custom provider.
Typically occurs because your request path is incorrect or your request JSON is invalid.

Typically occurs because your token is invalid. Obtain a new access token and then try again. See [Get started](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud-custom-provider/reference/get-started) for more information on configuring custom provider authentication.

schema.description: Typically occurs if your path includes an invalid customer ID or application ID. Verify those values are correct, then try again.

get.description: Returns your custom providers. Custom providers are social login identity providers (IdPs) that Akamai didn't predefine. You can configure most IdPs that support OAuth 2.0, OpenID Connect, or SAML 2.0 as custom providers.

externalDocs.description: See documentation for this operation in Akamai's Identity Cloud Custom Provider API

schema.description: Returns your custom providers. Custom providers are social login identity providers (IdPs) that weren't predefined by Akamai. You can configure most IdPs that support OAuth 2.0, OpenID Connect, or SAML 2.0 as custom providers.

_embedded.description: Navigable hypermedia links for your custom providers.

item.description: Navigable hypermedia links for the custom providers.

_links.description: Navigable hypermedia links for a custom provider.

self.description: Navigable hypermedia link for a custom provider.

id.description: Unique identifier of the custom provider.

protocol.description: **For use with OAuth, OpenID Connect, and SAML 2.0 providers.** Authentication protocol of the identity provider. Valid values: `oauth2`, for OAuth 2.0, `openidconnect` for OpenID Connect, and `saml2` for Security Assertion Markup Language 2.0. After you create a custom provider, you can't change the protocol.

_links.description: Navigable hypermedia links for a custom provider.

item.description: Navigable hypermedia links for a custom provider.

templated.description: Internal designator for the custom provider.

self.description: Navigable hypermedia link for a custom provider.

href.description: URL to all the custom providers in the application.

total.description: Total number of custom providers available to you.

schema.description: Typically occurs because your request path is incorrect or your request JSON is invalid.

Typically occurs because your token is invalid. Obtain a new access token and then try again. See [Get started](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud-custom-provider/reference/get-started) for more information on configuring custom provider authentication.

attribute_map.description:
**For use with OAuth, OpenID Connect, and SAML 2.0 providers.** Maps the user profile claims from a social login identity provider (IdP) to their corresponding Identity Cloud user profile attributes. For example, an IdP claim  `username` might map to the Identity Cloud’s `displayName` attribute. Without this mapping you can’t copy information from users' social login accounts to their Identity Cloud accounts. 
When creating a map, list the Identity Cloud attribute first and the IdP attribute second. For example, the mapping `"/displayName": "/username"` maps Identity Cloud’s `displayName` attribute to the social login provider’s `username` claim. You need to prepend each attribute name with the slash (`/`) character. See [Map custom provider attributes](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/map-custom-provider-attributes) for more information. 
This documentation shows only one sample attribute. The attributes available to you depend on the identity provider and on how you configure Identity Cloud.

auth_url.description: **For use with OAuth, OpenID Connect, and SAML 2.0 providers.** URL of the identity provider’s authorization server. For OpenID Connect and OAuth 2.0, find this value in the provider’s documentation or, for OpenID Connect only, by looking for the `authorization_endpoint` entry in the website’s discovery document. For SAML 2.0 providers you can determine the URL by retrieving the provider’s SAML metadata and looking for the `SingleSignOnService` element and the `Location` attribute. Regardless of the protocol, the value needs to use the `https` scheme.

authn_context.description:
**For use with SAML 2.0 providers.** Enables or disables the `RequestedAuthnContext` element in SAML requests. If not `null` this element instructs the SAML IdP to authenticate users by using a username and password. Typically this value makes no difference, because most SAML IdPs ignore the `RequestedAuthnContext` element. However, for some identity providers enabling this element prevents a user from authenticating. In those cases, use this member to disable the element. 
By default, Identity Cloud enables this member on all SAML providers prior to August 12, 2021 and disables it for providers after that date. If necessary, you can disable this member by setting the value to `null`.

class_ref.description: SAML authentication class. The only valid value is `PasswordProtectedTransport`, for use when a user authenticates with a password.

comparison.description: Specifies how the SAML provider determines the authentication flow. The supported `exact` value indicates the authentication context needs to match the `class_ref` exactly.

client_id.description: **For use with OpenID Connect providers.** Unique identifier of the authentication client users employ when logging in. The authentication client is the client you create on an identity provider’s developers site. Note that not all providers refer to this value as the _client ID_. Different providers might use such terms as _application ID_, _app ID_, or _API client ID_.  Use the `token_auth_method` member to specify to use how this member with an OAuth provider.

client_secret.description: **For use with OpenID Connect providers.** Password for the authentication client. Not all providers call this a _client secret_. Some providers might refer to an _application secret_ or _app secret_, while others might use the term _API secret_ or _API key_. Use the `token_auth_method` member to specify how to use this member with an OAuth provider.

createdAt.description: Timestamp indicating the creation date for the custom provider.

id.description: Unique identifier of the custom provider.

identifier_attribute.description: **For use with OAuth providers.** Attribute that uniquely identifies the user. For example, if the response from an OAuth provider includes a unique identifier `userid`, you might set the this member to `/userid`. Preface attribute names with `/`.

idp_certificate.description: **For use with SAML 2.0 providers.** X.509 certificate the identity provider uses to sign a SAML assertion. In a SAML assertion, the certificate is in the `<ds:X509Certificate>` section. In the `<ds:SignatureValue>` section you’ll find the public key, which authenticates the assertion.

idp_certificate_chain.description: **For use with SAML 2.0 providers.**  Certificates that complete the certificate chain. You only need this if you use a third-party Certificate Authority. If you use a self-signed SAML certificate, there’s no certificate chain to specify.

profile_url.description: **For use with OAuth and OpenID Connect  providers.** URL of the identity provider’s `userinfo` endpoint. This setting is in the provider’s documentation or, for OpenID Connect, by looking for the `userinfo_endpoint` entry in a website’s discovery document. The value needs to use the `https` scheme.

protocol.description: **For use with OAuth, OpenID Connect, and SAML 2.0 providers.** Authentication protocol of the identity provider. Valid values: `oauth2`, for OAuth 2.0, `openidconnect` for OpenID Connect, and `saml2` for Security Assertion Markup Language 2.0. After you create a custom provider, you can't change the protocol.

scopes.description: **For use with OAuth and OpenID Connect providers.** Specifies the user profile information the identity provider returns following authentication. Standard OpenID Connect scopes include `openid`, `email`, `phone`, `address`, and `profile`. However, many IdPs use custom scopes instead of, or in addition to, these standard scopes.

title.description: **For use with OAuth, OpenID Connect, and SAML 2.0 providers.** Name of the custom provider. Names need to be unique across a given social login application.

token_auth_method.description: **For use with OAuth providers.** Authentication method for calling the provider's token endpoint. Possible values are: `client_secret_post` or `client_secret_basic`. With`client_secret_post`, the client sends authentication information as part of the HTTP POST request body. With `client_secret_basic`, the client passes a user ID and password to the server as part of an `Authorization` header. For security reasons, only use the `client_secret_basic` method on a secure connection.

token_url.description: **For use with OAuth and OpenID Connect providers.** URL of the identity provider’s token endpoint. This setting is in the provider’s documentation or, for OpenID Connect only, by looking for the `token_endpoint` entry in the website’s discovery document. The value needs to use the `https` scheme.

ui.description: **For use with OAuth, OpenID Connect, and SAML 2.0 providers.** Specifies the custom provider name and icon that displays in the Hosted Login sign-in screen. This member consists of two key-value pairs: `title` and `icon_url`.

icon_url.description: URL to the publicly accessible image as shown on the sign-in screen. Icons can use either .PNG or .SVG files. If omitted, no icon displays on the sign-in screen.

title.description: Name of the custom provider as it appears in the sign-in screen. Titles need to contain at least two, but no more than 200, characters. You need to include this value if you use this member.

updatedAt.description: Timestamp indicating the last update time for the custom provider.

schema.description: Modifies a custom provider. Use custom providers to allow the use of social login identity providers that Akamai didn't predefine.

When creating a map, list the Identity Cloud attribute first and the IdP attribute second. schema.description: Typically occurs if your path includes an invalid customer ID or application ID. Verify those values are correct, then try again.
Typically occurs if the `Content-Type` header is invalid.

Typically occurs if your request specifies an invalid member name. This might occur because of a misspelling or incorrect letter casing for a member name. This can also occur if the request specifies  invalid data for the provider protocol type.

parameters.description: Unique identifier of an Akamai customer. To verify your Akamai customer ID, log in to Console and, on the **Manage Application** page, check the value of the `customer_id` setting.

parameters.description: Unique identifier of a custom provider. You can return the IDs of all your custom providers by using the [Get all the custom providers in an application](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud-custom-provider/reference/get-custom-providers) operation.
parameters.name: providerId
